channel.title: "Stealing" Global Events?
channel.description:
Ok, so I was wondering if its possible to allow java to recieve global events, as in if a key is pressed and the java window isnt selected.
Is this even possible with java, or would this involve making a dll or hacking javaw?

item.title: "Stealing" Global Events?
item.dc:creator: @Galook Galook
item.description:
@Galook wrote:

actually, i wanted to know too… java autoing programs dont really work if they run in the background and you need them to stop rigth away… you would have to go to ur app and click a button off or something like that… i wanted to know to so I could start and stop my programs by pressign a button like F7 or something. The closest thing that i got was pressing rint screen and checked to see if the clipboard changed :S

But, like mopar said: You cant with pure java.

Read full topic

item.title: "Stealing" Global Events?
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

no, im not trying to make a keylogger, but that is a good idea…

Yes, this probably might be possible with jni, but i have no experience with jni and minimal experience with c++ :\

Read full topic

item.title: "Stealing" Global Events?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Your not trying to make a key logger are you?

I could have swore I saw a way to do this with jni someplace, Ill look around for you.

Read full topic

item.title: "Stealing" Global Events?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Not possible using pure java. I suppose you could by using jni and creating a global keyboard hook, but I’m not sure exactly how it would be done. But wouldn’t it be easier using something like C++ instead?

Read full topic
